Despite being one of the most buoyant and trailblazing green energy generation technology, the effective applications of direct methanol fuel cell is challenging mostly due to unavailability of suitably efficient, durable and cost effective catalyst for methanol oxidation reaction. The key features those should be rendered in the electrocatalytic materials are: good electrical conductivity, high surface area, mesoporous structure, excellent chemical stability towards acidic and alkaline medium, and acceptable resistivity toward corrosion. In recent years, one such emerging area of electrocatalysts are metal organic frameworks and the corresponding derived composite materials. The object of this review is to provide an impression of recent progresses in the area of metal organic frameworks and their derivatives for methanol oxidation reaction. The review compiles the synthesis strategies of those framework materials and their derivatives that are extensively being used in methanol oxidation reaction. The electrocatalytic reactivity in correlation with the structure and surface properties of the framework materials are addressed in detail. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Methanol oxidation reaction Metal organic frameworks MOF derived supported metal catalysts MOF derived oxidic catalysts 1 Introduction At the present juncture of the energy crisis with non-renewable fossil fuels and associated environmental issues, finding sustainable green energy source is one of the primary concerns. In the context of energy security, methanol economy is an upcoming alternative energy solution proposed by Professor George A. Olah that would not only contribute to reducing energy consumption and emissions, but also can stimulate the economic growth [1]. Production of methanol as alternative feedstock [2–7] and smart utilization to generate energy are the two inherent parts of methanol economy [8,9]. The direct methanol fuel cell is a subcategory of a proton exchange membrane fuel cell in which the methanol economy is realized by using methanol as fuel [10]. In the overall reaction, methanol is electrochemically oxidized on a catalyst surface to generate the alternative energy. Following are the methanol oxidation reaction (MOR) in anode in acidic condition, and the corresponding cathodic reaction [11]: Anode reaction : C H 3 OH + H 2 O → C O 2 + 6 H + + 6 e − Cathode reaction : 3 2 O 2 + 6 e − + 6 H + → 3 H 2 O In alkaline direct methanol fuel cell, MOR happens with the help of O H − , which are the ion carriers, and therefore anion exchange membranes are used instead of proton exchange membrane. Following is the MOR in anode in alkaline condition [12,13]: Anode reaction : C H 3 OH + 6 O H − → C O 2 + 5 H 2 O + 6 e − One of the primary bottleneck of the effective performance of methanol fuel cell is the anodic MOR, where the complete oxidation of methanol to CO2 takes place with a very high overpotential. Fig. 1 depicts the plausible route map for CO2 generation form methanol through different intermediate molecules via direct and indirect pathways. However, the transformation mechanisms are poorly understood [14,15]. To bring down the overpotential, Pt-based anode catalysts are widely used for MOR [16–20]. The indirect mechanism provides the CO as a stable intermediate, which can adhere with the Pt-based anode material causing the CO-poisoning to lessen the kinetic rate of methanol oxidation [21–24]. Alongside this, the Pt-based anodes are associated with several inherent drawbacks such as high cost, and limited reserve etc. [25]. The high cost coupled with CO poisoning of the Pt-based anode catalyst limit its commercial application. Therefore, significant efforts have been made to develop alternative economical electrocatalysts for methanol oxidation. Almost 90% of the chemical processes involve at least one catalytic step, and in this regard, efficiency, cost, environmental impact are important parameters of catalysts [26]. For electrocatalytic applications, the catalytic materials should possess high surface area and quick transportation of electron and mass. Additionally, the sufficient porosity of the materials is a desirable criterion to adsorb the small methanol molecules. Therefore, while developing newer alternatives, following materials properties should be rendered: (i) good electrical conductivity (ii) large surface area (iii) mesoporous structure (iii) excellent chemical stability towards acidic and alkaline medium, and (iv) acceptable resistivity toward corrosion [27,28]. One such emerging area of electrocatalysts are metal organic frameworks (MOFs) and MOF derived composites [29–32]. MOFs are known as porous coordination polymers emerged as an extensive class of crystalline material with high porosity and enlarged surface areas [33–37]. They are built of the inorganic secondary building unit (metal ions or clusters) and organic linkers, which are connected by coordination bonds of moderate strength [38,39]. The activated MOFs via washing and evacuation procedures produce accessible micropore volumes with BET surface areas around 1000 - 4000 m2 g−1. Pore apertures or channel diameters of MOFs range from 0.3 to 3.4 nm with pore volumes of up to 1.5 or 2 cm3 g−1. This is highly beneficial for methanol adsorption, as the adsorption step is being the primary step of electrooxidation. Cr based MOF MIL-53 exhibited methanol adsorption as high as of 0.53 g−1 at p/p0 < 0.20 [40]. Another MOF, MIL-101exhibited high selective adsorption towards methanol than water [41]. However, most MOFs have very low electronic conductivity, which limits their application as stand-alone electrodes/catalysts for MOR in fuel cell [42]. Therefore surface functionalization to enhance the charge transfer kinetics have attracted significant attention for electrocatalytic applications [43–48]. At the same time MOFs are modified to composites with conducting supports of carbon to further enhance the electrical conductivity of the catalyst [49–51]. The MOF derived carbonaceous materials possess certain advantages: (i) the extremely high porosity for efficient mass transport; (ii) significant improvement of electrical conductivity for charge transfer; (iii) homogeneously and highly dispersed accessible active metal sites; (iv) nitrogen doped carbon due to pyrolysis of nitrogen based linkers; (v) single-atom metal sites etc [52]. Recently, there has been a significant amount of studies on MOR using MOFs and MOF derived composite materials as anodic catalysts. Some investigations reported superior current densities of anodic MOR at lower overpotentials compared to Pt based catalysts. There have also been evidences of incorporating noble metals on MOF and MOF derived composite materials to design a better CO tolerant MOR catalyst. However, in spite of recent surge of studies on MOR catalysis over MOFs and MOF derived composites, there is not a single review article that compiles and critically address the efficacy of MOF materials towards MOR activity. The objective of this review is to provide an overview of recent developments in the field of MOF and its derivatives for methanol oxidation reaction. The first part of this review discusses the various design strategies and synthesis procedures adopted for modifying MOFs and MOF-derived carbonaceous materials with variable surface area and morphology for enhanced MOR, while the latter half addresses the direct correlation of the surface, structural and electronic properties of MOF with their electrocatalytic efficacy. Finally, the perspectives on future route map to design of MOFs and MOF derived composites for MOR catalysis are provided. 2 Synthetic strategies for architectural variations in MOFs and MOF derived materials The design and synthesis of porous MOF materials have undergone a rapid development in the past two decades due to their wide range of applications. After nearly three decades since the first report on MOFs by Professor Omar Yaghi [53], almost 10,000 MOFs are now synthesized [54–56]. The synthesis of these MOFs are mainly executed by employing the solvothermal (or hydrothermal) and complexometric routes. At the same time, the MOF derived materials are mostly synthesized by high-temperature pyrolysis of the pristine framework precursors. 2.1 Complexation and solvothermal syntheses strategies for MOFs The surface characteristic of the MOFs plays a key role in electrocatalysis as it controls the active sites, adsorption, and electron transport process during the reaction. This surface properties of MOFs could be altered by introducing the wide varieties of organic linkers that contains different functional groups. Zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs) is a sub-set of MOFs with tetrahedral frameworks of transition metals with imidazolate anions and are widely explored in electrocatalytic applications [57–60]. The common method adopted for the synthesis of ZIF based materials is the complexation process, where the precursor metal ions and the linkers are usually taken in a solvent system (methanol/ammonia) with continuous stirring in ambient or elevated temperature conditions [34,49,61,62]. Zn based ZIF-8 is one of the materials of choice due to its high thermal stability, solvent tolerance and high resistance against hydrolysis in alkaline media during MOR. In 2015, Maybodi et al. synthesized quasi-spherical shaped ZIF-8 particles with a surface area of 1430 m2g−1 and pore volume 1.01 cm3g−1 from methanolic solution of Zn(NO3)2 and 2-methylimidazole [43]. The same ZIF-8 was prepared as thin film at oil-water interface by Hoseini et al. in 2019 [63], where aqueous solution of 2-methyl imidazole was reacted with Zn(OAc)2 in toluene solution. The organic solvent was gently added to the aqueous medium with nominal disturbance that resulted in formation of thin layers of ZIF-8. The ZIF-8 thin film exhibited rhombic dodecahedral shape with surface area 787.42 m2g−1 and pore volume 0.3435 cm3g−1. Whereas the ZIF-8 synthesized from the complexation process did not show any effective MOR activity, the ZIF-8 thin film exhibited a current density of 32.7 mA/cm2 in 0.5 M MeOH solution. Apparently, the oil-water phase synthesis method made ZIF-8 thin film a superior catalyst for MOR by host-guest chemistry mechanism in spite of its lesser surface area. ZIF-67 could be synthesized also by the same method of complexation [64]. Co-based ZIF-67 were prepared from complexation of Co(NO3)2.6H2O and 2-methylimidazole in solid phase and also in methanolic solution with a surface area of 1262 m2g−1 and pore volume 0.6715 cm3g−1 for efficient MOR applications [65]. Co-doping of secondary metal ions like Ni2+, Zn2+, Cu2+ in Co based ZIF can enhance the redox active sites and consecutively the electrical conductivity of the catalyst. A schematic of complexometric synthesis of mixed metal based ZIF with the linker 2-methylimidazole is presented in Fig. 2 . The incorporation of more than one metal in particular molar ratio exerted a weaker binding affinity to carbonaceous species (CO*) and to hydroxyl species (OH*) compared to single metal based ZIFs [66]. Conventional hydrothermal/solvothermal routes are adopted for the synthesis of MOFs with the capability to tune the morphology, surface area and other surface characteristics such as roughness for enhanced electron transfer in electrocatalytic reaction. These synthesis methods are carried out at relatively elevated temperatures, where the metal ions and organic linkers are kept in a hydrothermal bomb and the combination of temperature and pressure self-assemble to form the framework [67–71]. Nickel and cobalt based MOFs are extensively explored in electrocatalysis because of its redox nature and capability to form active sites for electron transfer [72–74]. Wu et al. tuned the morphology of Ni-based highly porous 3D MOF [Ni4(OH)4(TATB)4/3(BPE)2]-(CTGU-15) containing cubane [Ni4(OH)4] cluster by solvothermal synthesis with metal precursor Ni(ClO4)2•6H2O, 4′,4′'-s-triazine-2,4,6-tribenzoic acid (TATB) and trans-1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethylene (BPE) as linkers in N,N-dimethyl acetamide and deionized water as the solvents [75]. The mixture was placed in an autoclave and was heated at 120 ⁰C for a day under autogenous pressure. CTGU-15 made from [Ni4(OH)4] cluster had very high BET surface area (3537 m2g−1) and exhibited bi-microporous feature with well-defined micropores of 0.86 nm and 1.51 nm. The efficient catalytic activity was due to the unique active cubane [Ni4(OH)4] unit linked to the TATB ligands that resulted in a net porous structure with large pore volume and high surface area for the adsorption and diffusion of reactive species. Temperature, pressure, solvent and precursor may play a crucial role in solvothermal synthesis of MOF [71,76]. Ni-MOF synthesized from Ni(NO3)2.6H2O and 1,3,5 benzene tricarboxylic acid in EtOH and DMF (1:1) solvent at 85 ⁰C for a day in Teflon-lined autoclave exhibited a hexagonal, rod-like morphology [77]. Whereas, the same MOF prepared from Ni(OAc)2•4H2O and 1,3,5 benzene tricarboxylic acid in the ionic liquid solvent of 1-ethyl-3-methylimidazolium bromide at 180 ⁰C for 3 days exhibited irregular morphology [78]. The Ni-MOF synthesized from EtOH and DMF solvent demonstrated MOR activity with a current density of 11.5 mA cm−2 in 2 M MeOH at 50 mVs−1 scan rate, whereas the similar materials produced from ionic liquid demonstrated a current density of 30.0 mA cm−2 under the similar experimental conditions. Apparently, the usage of ionic liquid in the solvothermal synthesis method could enhance the electrical conductivity in MOF structure which resulted in the enhancement of current density by twofold by modifying the structure as a cage promoting guest host mechanism. Similar to Ni-MOF, Co-MOF-71 [79] and Co-BTC-MOF [44] was modified for enhanced electrocatalytic activity by solvothermal method of synthesis. Co-MOF-71 synthesized by solvothermal method using Co(NO3)2 and terephthalic acid for a day at 120 ⁰C had cubical morphology with voids for efficient adsorption of methanol. At the same time the pores absorbed water molecule for the complete oxidation of intermediated to CO2. Co-BTC-MOF was synthesized with Co salt and 1, 3, 5 benzene tricarboxylic acid (2:1) in DMF/H2O/C2H5OH (1:1:1) solvent by 3 hours stirring and sonication. Reaction mixture was heated for a day at 100 ⁰C. It had irregular shape with multiple ionic states of Co. Co's redox behavior and defects modified by solvothermal method facilitated the catalytic process. Porous MIL-110 is another class of MOF with Fe or Cr or Al metal ions is extensively explored in catalysis [80–83]. MIL-110(Al) with large surface area (927 m2g−1) obtained by hydrothermal synthesis at 210 ⁰C for 3 h using trimethyl 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate and Al(NO3)3.9H2O had a pore volume of 0.31 m3g−1 and exhibited enhanced methanol adsorption [80]. 2.2 Pyrolysis of MOFs for derived composites The synthesized MOFs are also exposed to different calcination temperatures that retains the typical framework topology, morphology, and porosity in the derived materials, however enhances the electrical conductivity. Moreover, the porous carbon materials enhance the effective active sites [84]. The thermal transformation of MOFs in presence of oxygen and/or in inert or controlled environment produces wide varieties of metal oxides or metal sulfides with carbonaceous support as shown in Fig. 3 [31,60,85]. Among the derivatives of MOFs, metal oxides have received particular interest in electrocatalysis owing to their thermal and chemical stability, ultrahigh surface area and ample pore structures inherited from the pristine precursor [86–91]. Co3O4 and NixCo3-xO4-y were synthesized by Antony et al. from pristine ZIF-67 and Ni supported ZIF-67 by annealing the MOFs at 350 ºC at the heating rate of 4 ºC min−1 for 1.5 h [92]. The synthesized NixCo3-xO4-y with nano cage morphology exhibited a significantly higher surface area (92 m2g−1) compared to Co3O4 (51 m2g−1). It would be interesting to compare the synthesis of NiCo2O4 from Co(NO3)2•6H2O and Ni(NO3)2•6H2O in diethylene glycol with rapid heating that had a surface area of only 11.4 m2g−1 [93], whereas NiCo2O4 made by conventional hydrothermal method exhibited surface area of 88.4 m2g−1 [94]. The approach of nano cage fabrication from MOF template by pyrolysis over conventional complexation/hydrothermal method improved the active surface area, which was favorable for electrode-electrolyte interaction in the catalytic reaction. Apart from pristine metal oxides, composites of metal/metal oxides/conducting support can readily be obtained with direct pyrolysis of MOFs under inert atmosphere. These class of composites provide beneficial features, inducing interfacial interactions and synergistic effects for overall enhancement of electrocatalytic properties. Rezaee and Shahrokhian constructed petal-like (Fig. 4 B) NiCo/NiO-CoO/nanoporous carbon composite (NPCC) from bimetallic Ni-Co/MOF on pyrolysis at 900 °C at a heating rate of 1 °C min−1 for 8 h under N2 atmosphere as in Fig 4A [95]. It offered a high surface area of 543 m2g−1 with easily accessible active sites. The synergistic effects of redox metal/metal oxide with carbon framework showed significant electrochemical performance. Co2+ and Ni2+ MOFs with L-aspartic acid as organic linker was calcined in air at 300 °C for 4 h with the heating rate of 2.5 °C min−1 by Qian et al for the synthesis of NF/Co3O4/NiCo2O4 as illustrated in Fig. 4C [96]. The morphology came out to be nano spindle arrays (Fig. 4(D)) with surface area of 77.40 m2g−1 that not only facilitated the fast diffusion of electrolytes but also made the active sites easily accessible. Porous carbonaceous nanostructures with tunable pore size, specific surface area, as well as facile hetero atom doping have been established as promising materials for various catalytic and electrocatalytic applications [97]. Pyrolyzation of Zn-MOFs at elevated temperatures in inert atmosphere can produce nitrogen doped porous carbon without metals due to low boiling point of metallic Z [49,88]. Li et al. incorporated Pd nanoparticles on ZIF-8 derived carbon [98], while Zhang et al. integrated the alloy PtRu on ZIF-8 derived carbonaceous material [99]. Both the materials exhibited a very high surface area. The enhanced surface area and highly dispersed metals on carbon showed MOR activity of 45.20 mA cm−2 over Pt/C and 435.8 mA mg−1 over PtRu/C. PtCo alloy grafted on N-doped 2D carbon (PtCo/NCS) was synthesized by pyrolysis of H2PtCl6/ZIF-67/graphene oxide at different temperatures under reducing environment as shown in Fig. 5 A [100]. With increase in pyrolysis temperatures, the size of PtCo particles increased, and the size dependent catalysis was observed in its MOR activity. Zhu et al. synthesized Pt supported on nitrogen doped porous carbon from the MOF Pt/ [Zn(bpdc)DMA].DMF by direct pyrolysis at 800 ⁰C under inert atmosphere of N2 for 3 h at a heating rate of 4 ⁰C min−1 [101]. The produced carbon had mesopores and macropores with surface area of 56 m2g−1. The material possessed better and more stable electrocatalytic activity for MOR than Pt/Vulcan carbon-72 because of the enhanced bond strength between Pt and N-doped support. 2.3 SACs from MOF based precursors Single atom catalysts (SACs) have emerged as forefront runner in electrocatalysis with their catalytic sites dispersed at the atomic level [102–104]. However, synthesis of SACs has always been a challenge as with such high dispersion of active sites/metals, the surface free energy enhances, and consequently results in aggregation. Liu et al. first reported the thermal conversion of MOFs to SACs in inert and oxygen atmospheres, respectively [105,106]. And subsequently, there have been sufficient work on design and synthesis of SACs from MOFs and their catalytic activity as reviewed in recent literature [104,107,108]. The strategies for SACs design based on MOFs can broadly be categorized in two sections: (i) MOF stabilized SACs, and (ii) MOF derived SACs. The MOF stabilized SACs are designed by pore confinement, coordination stabilization, metal node stabilization, etc. Due to the well-defined cavity structure of MOF, the spatial confinement has been attempted to create SACs by trapping metal molecules within MOF pores. It is very important to select metal precursors with suitable molecular size according to the pore size of the targeted. Highly reactive Fe SAs anchored in N-doped porous carbon with Fe-SAs loading of 2.16 wt% was prepared via pyrolysis of cage-encapsulated- MOF [109]. ZIF-8 was used as source for N-doped porous carbon. Ru(acac)3 was efficiently encapsulated in situ in ZIF-8 with only one Ru(acac)3 molecule trapped in one cage of ZIF-8, and only Ru1 single atoms were stabilized by the framework of ZIF-8 by subsequent thermal reduction treatment below the thermal decomposition temperature of ZIF-8 [110]. In the MOF-stabilized coordination stabilization strategy, the uniform coordination sites of ligands in the skeleton of MOFs anchor mononuclear metal precursors, and thus prevent migration and agglomeration of metal atoms. Jiang et al. synthesized aluminum-based porphyrinic MOF with Al(OH)O4 chains interconnected by the porphyrin linkers, which was further employed to anchor Pt(II) by its porphyrin centers [111]. Other nitrogen-containing ligands, such as bipyridine-, Salen-, and 1,10-phenanthroline-based linkers, might also offer empty coordination sites, just like porphyrin to a certain degree, for the immobilization of SACs. The third category of metal node stabilization strategy of MOF stabilized SACs, is attempted by employing functionalization of coordinatively unsaturated metal sites of MOFs. The additional metal ions, which bind to the original metal clusters with low coordination numbers, might be readily reduced to SACs. In Hf-MOF-808 and Zr-NU-1000 vanadium metal precursor was separated and bridged on metal nodes to form single atoms [112]. In addition to the direct immobilization of SA of metals, SACs are also synthesized by pyrolysis method due to the atomically dispersed metal ions by coordinated organic ligands in their structures similar to the methods described in Section 2.2. Li and co-workers have achieved the trapping of one Fe(acac)3 molecule into one cage of ZIF-8 to afford an isolated single-atom Fe/N-doped porous carbon catalyst after further pyrolysis for an efficient oxygen reduction reaction [109]. 3 MOFs for MOR 3.1 Pristine and metal doped MOFs The tetrahedrally-coordinated transition metal centers with imidazolate linkers in ZIF structures in combination with appropriate redox active metals provide efficient active sites for MOR. Ni doped ZIF-8 on carbon paste electrode (CPE) exhibited a current density of 0.744 mAcm−2 at a potential of 1.71 V vs RHE in 0.1 M NaOH and 0.005 M MeOH [43]. The large surface area of 1430 m2g−1, and the presence of Ni (II) ions that reacted with OH− to produce Ni(OH)2 via NiOOH were found to be responsible for methanol oxidation. Though the current density was not high enough, however the ZIF-8 based catalyst demonstrated a robust stability even after 50 repetitive cycles with a retention of 98.6% of its initial anodic current response. ZIF-8 is based on Zn metal, whereas the ZIF-67 is comprised of tetrahedrally coordinated Co with the same imidazolate linker. Nano porous Ni doped ZIF-67 on CPE exhibited slightly higher current density of 2.5 mAcm−2 at a potential of 1.71 V vs RHE than Ni doped ZIF-8 [65]. The highly porous Co based MOF provided larger spaces for Ni loading that created more active cites for methanol oxidation. It should be noted that the active site Ni in the previous two examples were not the part of MOF structure; rather it was only impregnated on the porous ZIF. In a similar method, Ni was also impregnated on porous Al-benzenetricarboxylate MIL-110 (MIL-110(Al)) for methanol electro-oxidation reaction [80]. 20% Ni over MIL-110 showed the high MOR activity with current density of 14.4 mAcm−2 at a potential of 1.71 V vs RHE in 0.1 M NaOH and 0.1 M MeOH at a scan rate of 10 mV s−1 with a catalytic rate constant of 0.96 × 103 cm3 mol−1 s−1. In contrast to impregnating Ni on MOFs, Ni based MOF was synthesized by Wang et al. with the help of ionothermal method utilizing ionic liquid as solvent as well as ligand [78]. The ionothermally synthesized MOF showed a very high current density of 90 mAcm−2 at a potential of 1.60 V vs RHE in 4 M MeOH and 0.5 M NaOH was observed over Ni-benzenetricarboxylate MOF. Cu benzenetricarboxylate MOF, HKUST-1 is another pristine MOF, which was studied for MOR activity without any other supporting active metal site [113]. However, due to the poor aqueous stability, the Cu-MOF was linked to the Au electrode surface with the help of linkers like mercaptoacetic acid and trimesic acid as described in the previous synthesis section. Electrochemical experiments showed that the current density obtained for the mercaptoacetic acid modified HKUST-1/Au was almost 28 times higher than that of bare bulk gold electrode and trimesic acid modified HKUST-1 electrode. The authors concluded that the weakly axially coordinating CuII sites in HKUST-1 with open coordination sites were responsible for electrochemical reactivity towards the methanol oxidation. Hoseini et al. demonstrated the MOR performance by Zn2+ in pristine nanostructured film of ZIF-8 at an oil–water interface [63]. The uniformly dispersed rhombic dodecahedral shaped ZIF-8 film showed a current density of 32.7 mAcm−2 in 0.5 M NaOH and 0.5 M MeOH, which was even higher than Pt thin film as shown in Fig. 6 . The cavity diameter of synthesized ZIF-8 calculated from BET experiment was found to be 1.22 nm, which was sufficient enough for ZIF-8 to act as a host for a methanol molecule (0.42 nm). Further, the authors claimed that the strain in the backbone structure of ZIF-8 enhanced its activity as a proton acceptor from methanol, and the transfer of proton from methanol to the N atom of imidazole linker was instrumental in efficient reactivity of methanol oxidation. 3.2 Bimetallic MOFs Apart from the utilization of mono metallic MOFs, bimetallic MOFs also revealed promising MOR efficacy due to accelerated charge transfer phenomenon. CoNi-ZIF on 2D layers of MoS2 exhibited remarkably high current density of 430.08 mAcm−2 at a potential of 0.6 V Vs RHE in 1 M KOH and 0.5 M MeOH [114]. The enhanced electrocatalytic activity of MoS2@CoNi-ZIF was attributed to the specific architecture of mesopores, alignment of epitaxial MoS2 and hierarchical voids that facilitated the diffusion of electrons to the active sites. The synergism between Ni2+, Co3+ and Mo4+ in MoS2@CoNi-ZIF could efficiently enhance the kinetics of methanol oxidation reaction. The proposed reaction mechanism over MoS2@CoNi-ZIF surface followed the path of CH3OHads → (CH2OH)ads → (CHOH)ads → (COH)ads → (CO)ads → CO2↑. The same group recently explored the semiconducting bimetallic 2D MOFs as a platform for charge carriers. The 2D semiconducting MOFs have already established their importance in electro catalysis due to high charge mobility through planar p-delocalization, and out of plane π– π stacking [115–117]. Cui et al. synthesized bimetallic MOF of Co and Ni with a conjugated linker hexaaminobenzene (HAB) [118]. CoxNi3-x(HAB)2 showed methanol oxidation activity with a current density of 92.8 mAcm−2 at a potential of 1.6 V vs RHE in 1 M KOH and 0.5 M MeOH. The synergism between the multiple oxidation states of Co and Ni in 2D layers along with metal-N coordination centers made it an efficient catalyst. The combination of Ni and Co in cubane based MOFs like [M4(OH)4] (M = Ni, Co) showed MOR activity with a high current density of 527 mAmg−1 at a potential of 1.46 V vs RHE in 0.1 M KOH and 1 M MeOH [75]. The efficient electron transport and electrolyte access between cubane [M4(OH)4] unit and ligand with very high BET surface area (3537 m2g−1) and bi-microporous feature apparently were instrumental in efficient MOR activity. One of the latest work by Ali Pashazadeh and Biuck Habibi was Ni ions incorporated Zn mesoporous MOFs on the surface of glassy carbon (Ni/Zn-MOFs/GCE) for electrocatalytic MOR in alkaline medium [119]. The incorporation of Nil to Zn MOF exhibited a current density of 300 µA at 1.56 V vs RHE, which could be attributed by the active center (NiOOH) with high surface area and high electrical conductivity for MOR electro-oxidation. The study indicated that the doping of electroactive sites in MOFs is a route to fabricate efficient electrocatalysts for MOR applications. 3.3 MOFs with conducting filler The conductivity of the MOF is always an inherent issue associated with its electrocatalytic performances. Therefore, conducting carbon supports like graphene and its derivatives are explored in combination with MOF for MOR applications. Composite of Co-benzenedicarboxylate MOF with 5 wt.% graphene oxide (Co-BDC/5wt% GO) prepared by hydrothermal method exhibited a current density of 291 mAcm−2 in 1.77 V vs RHE for MOR in 1 M KOH and 3 M MeOH [79]. In another study, Co-benzenetricarboxylate MOF with 1 wt.% reduced graphene oxide (CO-BTC/1 wt% MOF) exhibited a current density of 130 mAcm−2 at 1.59 V vs. RHE in 1 M NaOH and 2 M MeOH [44]. Some research groups have demonstrated that the higher amount of reduced graphene oxide may reduce the current density as the sheets restacked and blocked of active sites and also the surface adsorption of hydroxyls hindered the methanol from oxidation. Ni-benzenetricarboxylate MOF on 4 wt.% reduced graphene oxide (Ni-BTC/ 4wt% rGO) exhibited a current density of 200.22 mAcm−2 at 1.61 V vs RHE electrode at 50 mV s−1 in 1 M NaOH and 2 M MeOH [77]. In another work, Ni-benzenedicarboxylate MOF over reduced graphene oxide (Ni-BDC/rGO)_did show a current density of 275.85 mAcm−2 at 1.8 V vs RHE in 3 M MeOH and 1 M NaOH [74]. The improved electrocatalytic activity was due to the synergistic correlation between the MOF and the graphene oxide sheets. The methanol adsorption took place into the voids of MOF, and was further enhanced by the presence of graphene oxide. The electrochemical oxidation proceed via CH3OHads → (CH2OH)ads → (CHOH)ads → (COOH)ads → CO2 route over the Ni-MOF catalyst. Following the work on Ni based MOF, Cu-benzenetricarboxylate MOFs on graphene oxide (Cu-BTC/GO) also gained attention in MOR catalysis [120]. For instance, 5 wt.% graphene oxide with octahedral Cu-benzenedicarboxylate exhibited methanol oxidation activity of 120 mAcm−2 in 3 M MeOH and 1 M KOH at 1.8 V vs RHE. The presence of graphene oxide in Cu-benzenedicarboxylate generated pores in extended surfaces and consequently reduced the activation energy for MOR. The bimetallic Ni-Cu benzenedicarboxylate MOF in composite with reduced graphene oxide (Ni-Cu-BDC/rGO) could enhance the methanol oxidation activity with a current density of 437.8 mAcm−2 in 3 M MeOH and 1 M NaOH [121]. However, the methanol oxidation started at a higher potential of 1.8 V vs RHE. Highly robust two pseudo-isomeric Ni-based MOFs, CTGU-17 and CTGU-18 with 1,4-naphthalenedicarboxylate and 4,4′-dipyridyl amine linkers simultaneously were successfully synthesized for MOR applications as shown in Fig. 7 [122]. The MOFs were integrated with conducting acetylene black for enhanced electrochemical activity. The highest MOR activity was exhibited by CTGU-18/acetylene black (CTGU-18/ AB) with current density of 442.3 mAmg−1 in 0.1 molL−1 KOH and 1 molL−1 MeOH at 1.66 V vs RHE. The active {Ni2(COO)4N2} units of Ni in synergistic combination with AB were responsible for the enhanced MOR activity. A comprehensive list of MOF catalysts with their performances is provided in Table 1 . 4 MOF derived composites for MOR As discussed, the pristine MOFs suffer from the conductivity issues, one of the solution was to support it on conducting carbon derivatives. The other approach to overcome the conductivity issue while retaining the surface area and porosity is pyrolyzing the MOF at inert or reducing atmosphere to produce the metal or metallic alloys supported on conducting carbon. On the other hand, pyrolysis of MOFs in oxidizing atmosphere would result in oxidic materials with high surface area and porosity that enable the active sites available for methanol oxidation. MOF derived carbon composites would also possess high chemical and mechanical stabilities [123,124]. In the following sections, we would mostly focus on MOF derived composites for MOR. 4.1 MOF derived materials with zero valent metals Alloying any other transition metal with Pt is a popular choice in this method to overcome the CO poisoning issue along with the lessening of the cost for the catalyst as the weight percentage of the precious metal is reduced significantly than the pristine one [125]. Pyridine based MOF, [Zn(bpdc)DMA].DMF was pyrolyzed at elevated temperatures to synthesize nitrogen-doped porous carbons and was later embedded with metallic Pt [101]. The current density of the MOF derived material for MOR was 5 mAcm−2 at 0.88 V vs RHE in 0.5 M H2SO4 and 0.5 M methanol. Recently, PtCo alloy over nitrogen doped carbon was synthesized by high temperature calcination of graphene oxide/ZIF-67/H2PtCl6 [100] that showed an remarkable resistance towards CO due to the electronic synergism between the two metals, and exhibited a current density of 1.25 mAcm−2, which was 2.6 times higher than commercial Pt/C. In another recent work of PtCo alloy over N-doped carbon nanotube derived from high temperature calcination of ZIF-67 and melamine exhibited MOR mass activity of 700.3 mA mg−1 of Pt, which was 4.5 times higher than commercial Pt/C [126]. The improved efficacy of the catalyst was due to the formation of Co-Nx bonds and better dispersion of Pt nano particles. Partial galvanic replacement method was adopted by Long et al. to produce Cu@Pt/C from Cu-MOF [127]. The material had octahedral morphology with 20–80 nm sized uniformly distributed Pt nano particles that enhanced the electrochemical active surface area to 74.3 m2g−1 compared with Pt/C (50.4 m2g−1). Cu@Pt/C unveiled excellent efficacy of 624 mAcm−2 mg−1Pt in 0.5 M MeOH and 0.5 M H2SO4 at 50 mV s−1 scan rate. The changes in the electronic structure induced by core-shell structure of Cu@Pt/C reduced the energy barriers of methanol adsorption and oxidation. The bimetallic alloy of PtNi/C derived from Pt/Ni-benzenedicarboxylate-MOF exhibited MOR activity of 27.28 mAcm−2 in 0.5 M MeOH and 0.5 M H2SO4 at a potential of 0.88 V vs RHE [128]. The electronegativity difference between the metals resulted in transfer of electron from Ni to Pt that reduced the density of states on the Fermi level and improved the MOR activity. Additionally, NiOOH/Ni(OH)2 species over Ni sites were also attributed to the high MOR activity. The bimetallic PtRu was highly dispersed over nitrogen doped conducting mesoporous carbon derived from ZIF-8 (PtRu/NMPCs) for MOR catalysis [99]. The doping of N atoms well anchored the evenly sized PtRu nano particles and also enhanced the electrical conductivity and mechanical stability of the composite. The BET surface area of the composite was very high (1960 m2g−1) with enlarged pore volume (1:16 cm3g−1). The observed current density of 435.8 mAcm−2 at 0.215 V vs RHE in 0.5 M H2SO4 and 0.5 M MeOH over the synthesized composite was higher than the commercial analogue. Like Pt, Pd was also embedded on porous carbon material derived from MOFs. Li et al. synthesized hierarchically porous carbon by carbonization of ZIF-8 and impregnated Pd on it (Pd/ZC-1000) for enhanced MOR activity [98]. A methanol oxidation current density of 45.20 mAcm−2 at 1.25 V vs RHE in 1 M KOH and 1 M MeOH was exhibited by the catalyst. The unique 3D framework structure of pyrolysed carbon offered high surface area and high graphitic degree, which made it a prospective catalyst for methanol electro-oxidation. Nitrogen atoms from the imidazole linker was doped in the pyrolysed catalyst structure that interacted with the methanol via hydrogen bonds, and accelerated the charge mobility for oxidation reaction. Pd was also loaded on to Cu/C (Pd-Cu/C) which was prepared through calcining the Cu- benzenedicarboxylate MOF (HKUST-1) under a N2 atmosphere [129]. The schematics of the synthesis is projected in Fig. 8 A. The material exhibited a current density of 4643 mAmg−1 Pd at a potential of 1.10 V vs RHE in 1 M KOH and 1 M MeOH. The presence of Cu with Pd increased CO oxidation as Cu binds CO more strongly than Pd and therefore prevented the electrode from CO poisoning. As a result, the catalytic activity of Pd–Cu/C was found to be 13 times higher than commercial Pd/C for methanol oxidation (Fig. 8C). In the above studies, the noble metals were incorporated on the MOF by impregnation method before pyrolysis. The major drawback in the impregnation method is coalescence of the active metal sites under the durability studies. On the contrary, incorporation of Pt in the MOF lattice would result in homogeneous distribution of the active site after pyrolysis. In Hofmann-type MOF [Fe(L)nPt(CN)4] (, where n can be 1 for bridging and 2 for monodentate ligand), the Pt atoms are connected with the Fe atoms through the CN− groups, and provide a combined framework of noble and base metals. The pyrolysis lead to highly dispersed Pt3Fe over carbon, which was then grown on graphene oxide to increase its mechanical stability and conductivity (Fig. 9 (A, B). The composite showed a current density of 50 mAmg−1 at 0.75 V vs RHE in 0.1 M H2SO4 and 1 M MeOH [130]. With the increase of pyrolysis temperature, the increase degree of graphitization of carbon simultaneously enhanced the conductivity and charge transfer kinetics of the catalyst to exhibit better MOR efficacy (Fig. 9C). Other than noble metals, metallic nano alloy CoCu synthesized by pyrolyzing ternary-metallic zeolitic imidazolate MOFs also showed promising MOR activity of 419 Ag−1 at a potential of 1.66 V vs RHE [66]. The synergistic electrochemical interaction of Co showing strong binding affinity to the intermediates CO* and OH*, whereas Cu exhibiting a moderate binding affinity to the intermediates were believed to be the critical factors for efficient MOR activity. 4.2 MOF based SACs SACs with atomically dispersed active sites have recently emerged as a new frontier in electrocatalysts for fuel cells, Zn–air battery, water splitting and CO2 reduction applications [109,131–135]. Interestingly, atomically dispersed Pt on Au octahedral [136] and single-atom of Pt immobilized in covalent triazine frameworks did not show remarkable activity for the MOR [137]. However, the exploration of MOF based SACs are still at infancy. 4.3 MOF derived oxides MOF derived rock salts, spinels and other oxides were also actively implemented as novel electrodes for MOR. Nano cages of mesoporous NixCo3-xO4-y produced from MOF based template route using Ni2+/ZIF-67 stood as an excellent candidate for MOR [92]. The catalyst exhibited a current density of 200 Ag−1 at 1.41 V vs RHE in 1 M KOH and 1 M MeOH. The value was 12 times higher than Co3O4 derived from pristine ZIF-67. The presence of more than one metals in the catalyst in non-stoichiometric amount not only increased the catalytic activity but also minimized the rate of CO poisoning. As, CO preferentially binds to Co than Ni and MeOH favors Ni as a binding site, the simultaneous presence of Ni and Co made the catalyst CO tolerant [138]. The lower values for Rads (9±0.15Ω) for NixCo3-xO4-y indicated the favorable adsorption of MeOH on Ni and CO on Co sites. Composites of spinels derived from MOF was further supported on conducting materials for superior catalytic activity for methanol oxidation. The hollow porous Co3O4 nano-spindle arrays were derived from ZIF-67 and grown on nickel foam (NF) [96]. Further, the NiCo2O4 nanotubes were in-situ grown on NF/Co3O4 3D structure using a Co-Ni-aspartic acid coordination precursor to provide an ordered porous NF/Co3O4/NiCo2O4 electrode for MOR. The final catalyst was prepared by the pyrolysis of NF/Co3O4/CoNi-aspartic acid in air at 300 °C for 4 h that exhibited MOR activity of 140 mAcm−2 at 1.46 V vs RHE in 0.5 M MeOH and 1 M KOH at 10 mV s−1 scan rate. The superior catalytic activity was endowed to the hollow structure with well-dispersed electrocatalytic active sites and efficient contact between electrode and electrolyte for competent mass diffusion. Presence of the 3D Co3O4 skeleton afforded more surface area, flexibility, and strong adhesion for the in situ growth of NiCo2O4 nanotubes to exhibit the higher MOR efficacy. Composites of rock salt derived from mixed metallic MOFs was explored by Rezaee et al. for MOR [95]. The authors synthesized petal-like NiCo/NiO-CoO from bimetallic Ni-Co-benzenedicarboxylate MOF. The active sites of NiCo/NiO-CoO was supported on ultrathin nano porous carbon by pyrolysis in N2 atmosphere at 900 °C. The morphologically modified composite catalyst material displayed a surface area of 543 m2g−1 with larger and broader pore size of 19 nm, which was found to be favorable for electrochemical reaction. The composite exhibited a current density of 178 mAcm−2 at a potential of 0.84 V vs. RHE in 0.5 M NaOH and 0.5 M MeOH at 50 mV s−1 scan rate. The unique petal-like nanostructures with interconnected nano sheets had high BET surface area that endowed the active sites available and shortened the diffusion pathways for charge transfer, which finally lowered the overpotential and consecutively enhanced the electrocatalytic activity for MOR. Pt-WC/W24O68/NCZ8 synthesized from ZIF-8 exhibited significantly higher mass activity (2492.2 mA mg−1 Pt) than the commercial 10 wt.% Pt/C (499.2 mA mg−1 Pt) in 0.5 M H2SO4 and 0.5 M MeOH [139]. The authors claimed that hydrogen atoms during MOR were inserted into W24O68 and produced HyWO3 (0 < y < 1) that enhanced the electrical conductivity of the overall co-catalyst system and improved the MOR efficacy. Moreover, the charge transfers and ion diffusion paths are reduced by the special rod like structure of W24O68 with abundant oxygen vacancies. Similar to the former work, Gong et al. synthesized Pt/ W18O49 with focus on oxygen vacancies and two valence states of W (W5+ and W6+) in W18O49 for promoting in MOR. At the same time, Pt doping on W18O49 improved the anti-poisoning properties of the intermediate CO [140]. Ta2O5 spheres anchored to ZIF-8 derived ZnO petals (ZnO@Ta2O5) showed MOR activity of 117 mAcm−2 in 0.5 M MeOH and 1 M KOH at potential of 1.56 V vs RHE [141]. Zn(OH)2 and ZnOOH were believed to be the active site, which were formed on reaction of OH− with Zn(II). Another fascinating MOF derived material was porous TiO2@NC composites (TiO2@NC−NCNTs) derived from spindle type bimetallic (Ti/Co) benzenedicarboxylate MOF as shown in Fig. 10 A [142]. Fig. 10(B–E) show the micrographs of the synthesized catalysts. After decorating the Pt-nanoparticle on to the TiO2@NC−NCNTs, the nanocomposite exhibited superior MOR activity with the current density of 577 mAmg−1Pt (in acidic medium) and 3100 mAmg−1Pt (in alkaline medium) in 0.5 M MeOH (Fig 10(F and G)). The superior methanol oxidation activity was attributed to the appropriate introduction of Co metal in Ti-benzenedicarboxylate MOFs that created defects and high graphitization in N-doped carbon. The hydroxyl groups on TiO2 surface could avoid the catalytic CO poisoning and retained the structural integrity of the composite catalyst system under harsh acidic and alkaline electrochemical conditions. A comprehensive list of MOF derived catalysts with their performances is provided in Table 2 . 5 Conclusion and outlook Apparently, the chemistry of MOFs and MOF derived composites have progressed substantially and established to be a promising material for MOR based on its active sites, porous nature and ability for electrocatalytic activity, effective mass transfer and excellent chemical and pH stability. Different synthetic strategies such as solvothermal, complexometric methods have been adopted to obtain the fine-tuned MOFs focusing on roughness parameters with desired morphology and porosity. The pyrolysis to carbonization or in oxygen atmosphere to yield different structured oxides retained the surface area and porosity while overcome the conductivity issues. During the pyrolysis process, the organic moiety of MOF precursors transforms into carbon materials. Meanwhile, the metal moiety evaporates under high temperature, or remains in the carbon matrix in many possible forms, including SACs and metal-containing nanoparticles. By choosing proper MOF precursors, carbon- or metal-based active materials for MOR electrocatalysis can be obtained in the MOF-derived carbon-based materials. In spite of amazing developments, pristine MOFs and MOF-derived materials are till date in their initial stages for methanol oxidation reaction and in consecutive shaping up for appropriate fuel cell applications. Although more than some thousands of MOFs have been synthesized, only a few of them have been explored for MOR efficacy. There is an ample amount of opportunity to build newer MOFs and their derivatives for electrocatalytic applications. It must be noted that pyrolysis processes involve high temperatures for the transformation from MOFs to carbon-based materials, which is not an economically suitable way for large scale industrial synthesis. Therefore, more rigorous efforts should be devoted to the design and economic synthesis of MOF precursors and their derivatives for MOR applications and its industrial utilizations. For industrialization purpose the inexpensive precursors should be chosen and precise control over the porosity of MOF-derived materials should be taken care of. Also sometimes the original pore structure of MOFs collapses during pyrolysis, and the newly formed pore structure inside the MOF-derived carbon matrix is hard to control. Therefore, it is challenging and worth exploring to achieve controllable pore structure design in the carbon matrix during pyrolysis to enhance the mass transport for electrocatalytic reactions. Electrocatalysis is a surface phenomenon influenced by structural properties. Therefore, extensive researches are required to understand the bulk structure, and surface properties of the synthesized MOFs, and MOF derived materials. In situ structural characterizations during MOR is required, and this is not exclusively exhausted in present literature. The oxygen evolution reaction, the analogous anodic oxidation reactions to MOR is more explored in terms of rationalizing the descriptors. However, the studies on electronic properties of MOFs and MOF derived materials to identify the descriptor in correlation with MOR mechanism and activity is still at infancy. For MOR electrochemical tests, standard testing conditions and methods should be established and attempts should be made to scale up the process. The present review indicates that though the MOF based SACs are well explored for various electrocatalytic processes, however is less studied for MOR activity. There is a huge scope of exploring the SACs towards MOR catalysis. The fundamental electrode design of SACs for practical application should be adequately studied. In view of the long-term development, the MOF based SACs may go a long way. Therefore, industry and academia should immensely collaborate to bridge the gap to convert lab efforts into the practical applications. coredata.dc:description: Despite being one of the most buoyant and trailblazing green energy generation technology, the effective applications of direct methanol fuel cell is challenging mostly due to unavailability of suitably efficient, durable and cost effective catalyst for methanol oxidation reaction. The key features those should be rendered in the electrocatalytic materials are: good electrical conductivity, high surface area, mesoporous structure, excellent chemical stability towards acidic and alkaline medium, and acceptable resistivity toward corrosion. In recent years, one such emerging area of electrocatalysts are metal organic frameworks and the corresponding derived composite materials. The object of this review is to provide an impression of recent progresses in the area of metal organic frameworks and their derivatives for methanol oxidation reaction. The review compiles the synthesis strategies of those framework materials and their derivatives that are extensively being used in methanol oxidation reaction. The electrocatalytic reactivity in correlation with the structure and surface properties of the framework materials are addressed in detail.
coredata.dc:title: A compendium on metal organic framework materials and their derivatives as electrocatalyst for methanol oxidation reaction
